index.subtitle: JavaScript
index.about: JavaScript is a lightweight, interpreted, object-oriented language with first-class functions, most known as the scripting language for Web pages, but used in many non-browser environments as well such as Node.js or Apache CouchDB. It is a prototype-based, multi-paradigm scripting language that is dynamic, and supports object-oriented, imperative, and functional programming styles.

videos.title: ES6 Generators
videos.description: Generators! In this episode we introduce you to working lazily with complex array calculations with generators.

videos.title: Functions Scope Basic
videos.description: This or that? Javascript scoping can be confusing. This lesson covers the very basics of function scoping.

videos.title: Introduction to Lodash
videos.description: Lodash is a toolkit of Javascript functions that provides clean, performant methods for manipulating objects and collections. It is a 'fork' of the Underscore library and provides additional functionality as well as some serious performance improvements. If you aren't using Lodash, you should be.

videos.title: Intro to ES6 Traceur compiler
videos.description: ES6 is the next generation of javascript. You can use it today with the traceur compiler library. Also be sure to check out es6fiddle to start playing with ECMAscript 6 right now.

videos.title: ES6 Arrow function
videos.description: ECMAscript 6 introduces the 'arrow function' as a shortcut for creating anonymous functions with this scope bound.

videos.title: ES6 Array comprehensions
videos.description: With ECMAscript 6 you have access to powerful array comprehensions for generating new arrays from existing arrays based on criteria you specify.

videos.title: ES6 String templates
videos.description: ECMAscript 6 lets us use string templates to gain a lot more control over strings in JavaScript.

videos.title: ES6 Generators
videos.description: Generators in ECMAscript 6 are first-class coroutines that produce encapsulated suspended execution contexts. Whew! Yield values and iterate over them until no more values exist in the generator. We'll talk more about practical use later.

videos.title: Introduction to ECMAScript 6
videos.description: Welcome to What's Coming to JavaScript. ECMAScript 6 introduces many new features to the language. We won't look at all of them, but we will spend time with the big new features that will fundamentally change the way we write JavaScript.

videos.title: Picking the ECMAScript 6 environment
videos.description: Because ES6 is not finalized, we will not find an environment that implements 100% of the specification. There are two environments we'll use: Google Traceur and Firefox Nightly

videos.title: SOLID JS In A Wobbly World Wide Web
videos.description: In this episode, you’ll see the following SOLID principles covered and see how they apply to JavaScript.

videos.title: AMD Build With Grunt And Rigger
videos.description: In this episode, you’ll see: UMDJS, Project Dependencies with NPM, Grunt-Rigger and AMD Build.

videos.title: The Jasmine Standalone Runner
videos.description: In this episode I will show you the basics of how to install and use the standalone version of the Jasmine testing framework, to write unit tests for your JavaScript applications.

videos.title: ES6 Arrow Functions
videos.description: Arrow functions are a short, succinct syntax for building functions in ES6. Not only do they make for more powerful functional code, they also help inside of callback by lexically binding this.

videos.title: ES6 Template Strings
videos.description: Template strings will make it easy to build strings, localize strings, and sanitize HTML. A marvelous addition to JavaScript.

videos.title: ES6 Rest Parameters
videos.description: Rest parameters make functions with a variable number of arguments easy, readable, and safe.

videos.title: ES6 Default Parameter Values
videos.description: There is a new syntax to provide default values for missing parameters.

videos.title: ES6 Spread
videos.description: The spread is syntactic sugar we can use to spread an array across function parameters, or into an array literal.
